title: #135 – BJ Miller, M.D.: How understanding death leads to a better life
content: BJ Miller is a hospice and palliative care specialist on a quest to reframe our relationship with death. In this episode, BJ begins with how his own brush with death radically shifted his perspective and ultimately forged his path towards palliative care and helping patients integrate and understand their life in a meaningful way. BJ recounts several moving stories from his patients, which reveal important lessons about overcoming the fear of death, letting go of regret, and what’s most important in life. He discusses the major design flaws of a “death phobic” healthcare system. Furthermore, he makes the case that seeing death as a part of life allows us to live well, as opposed to living to evade death itself. He concludes with a discussion around physician-assisted death as well as his hopes around the use of psychedelics to reduce suffering in end-of-life care. He also provides insight into the factors that contribute to the stress response (and our ability to handle it) such as social rank, personality, environment, and genetics. Lastly, we discuss how our behavior is altered in the face of stress and how that not only has a pervasive effect on a personal level, but also on society as a whole in how we interact with each other. Connect With Peter on Twitter, Instagram, Facebook and YouTube Download Download Subscribe Subscribe Share Share § Show NotesBJ’s accident leading to the loss of his limbs and his experience inside a burn unit [3:00] Life-altering event Shortly after Thanksgiving in 1990, BJ was in college at Princeton at the time He was out having a drink with friends and climbed on top of a non-operating commuter train as a goof  He got too close to the electrical line above the train the electricity entered through his metal watch on his my left arm and then ground down causing an explosion He ended up losing both legs below the knee and his left arm below the elbow and spent months in the burn unit What does he remember from the night? Very little, doesn’t remember getting shocked His first memory was being awkwardly loaded onto a helicopter as the paramedics were trying to vent the heat from his body (With electrical burns, you burn from the inside out, so you’ve got all this heat running around in your system and it’ll keep burning you) Life inside the burn unit “It is another world that I’ve always struggled to impart to people what it’s actually like in there. It is a wholly unnatural place. I mean, nature is completely kept at bay.” —BJ Miller on the working conditions inside a burn unit A burn unit is a very different place that requires specialized doctors and nurses The grotesque nature of the disfiguration of the skin These dressing changes several times per day on a patient require incredible sterility at the bedside Even the smell of burned tissue is a very foreign odor to people Risk of infection Infection is very often the thing that kills people, hence all the sterility Someone might look just fine, but their survival odds can be quite low because their body is so susceptible to infection There is no touching allowed (hard for BJ and his parents)   Coping with his amputations—being tough, the grieving process, and the healing properties of tears [14:30] Why the need to amputate limbs? When fasciotomies are performed initially, it’s with the hope of salvaging the limbs They came to the realization trying to salvage the limbs was actually going to threaten BJ’s life due to infection The conversation with the surgeon One night, BJ had a memory of the conversation regarding amputation with the surgeon When he awoke the next morning, he was in a daze and remembers thinking, “Thank god that was just a dream.” In his hazy state, BJ managed to extubate himself, put out the central lines in this neck, get out of bed and start to walk to the bathroom About halfway there, the catheter line ran out of slack and it yanked on the Foley, “that’s a pain that I won’t soon forget.” At that point, clarity hit him—he knew at that point that the amputation conversation wasn’t a dream “It was instantaneous that I realized this wasn’t a dream. And all the relief that I had experienced moments ago in the other direction just immediately went away, and I was very, very clear where I was and what was happening to me. Instantaneously. It was a wild, wild moment I won’t soon forget.” —BJ Miller Figure 1. Photo of BJ’s new body. Image credit: dailymail.co.uk BJ’s process of mourning the loss of his limbs His conscious mourning process was delayed, he thought the thing to do was to pick yourself up, be tough, and get back on the horse, “The less you acknowledge what’s gone on, the better. The tougher you are, the faster you’ll be functional again.” Weird level of immediate acceptance: BJ’s mom has been disabled due to polio her whole life, so in his first conversation with her was almost an excitement to be able to relate with her, “now we have so much more in common” It wasn’t a thorough acceptance, “It was where I wanted to be, but it wasn’t really where I was.” He was on autopilot in a way First time he let it out— A nurse one day urged BJ to let his real feelings out, told him she was sick of him not taking this seriously and acting too cheery, “This is a big, big deal. You’re not being real.” BJ began to cry, like a dam had been broken, “It was the most magical thing.” Tears as a form of anesthesia? BJ had a fascinating moment when crying, he felt no physical pain It was a fascinating moment, and the beginning of a long process of months and years of mourning and grieving What was the underlying source of BJ’s sadness and tears? A release of the physical pain: “I had just been literally gritting my teeth and trying to feel or act as strong” Shame and embarrassment: The sorrow came a bit from embarrassment for doing this and putting his parents through so much pain Fear of going through life disabled: would ever have sex again, what women were going to think of me, what my friends would think of me, he has seen the cruelty towards diabled people before Very low on the list was the “Why me?” questions: if anything, he felt guilty for having too perfect a life before that   Going from art history to medical school: the value of a diverse background in medicine [28:15] How the death of his sister altered his path BJ had a sister who was 4 years older than him He really looked up to her and found her to be a very insightful person, “Wild, brilliant, fascinating, just intense person.” BJ says he “chased her moods around. Anything she told me, I took at face value. I mean, she owned me in so many ways as her younger brother.” Turns out she was also very troubled Roughly 10 years after BJ’s accident, his sister committed suicide At the time, BJ was in medical school and this event precipitated his decision to leave medicine How BJ decided to go into medicine While in recovery, BJ said it was “like a torture chamber interspersed with incredible boredom” He spent a lot of time pondering questions of meaning and identity in a way that was very relevant and therapeutic and practical: “What am I now? Am I less of a person? Do I have less to offer the world?” He was looking for meaning-making— i.e., how humans work with pain, how did humans work with things they can’t control This led to his fascination with art — It’s kind of a stunning impulse that human beings have—“That was lighting up for me as very important and telling and that maybe, maybe the art world had something to teach me.” He returned to Princeton and switched his major to art history *Advice for college students on what to study prior to med school: Peter’s general advice: Anything but pre-med Peter values a diverse background And most of everything you study in pre-med, you’re going to pick up in medical school anyway BJ agrees, “If you’re going to go into the healing professions, the clinical professions, you better find a way to delve into why life is amazing and horrifying” questions around meaning and identity have been “crowded out” of healthcare BJ says he really, really loves the notion of people who study humanities then going into the healing professions ⇒ Peter gave his thoughts on this topic in AMA #3 and the episode with David Epstein The medical field benefits from physicians with a wide range of backgrounds— Medicine needs all of the above: People who have probably gone incredibly deep on a very narrow subset of science, engineering backgrounds, humanities backgrounds, etc. Pre-med is not bad, says BJ: “Just make sure you actually love it. Just make sure you love the nuts and bolts so you’re not just doing chemistry just as a means to the end of medical school. You find something to study that actually cultivates you loving something—I think that’s a major, major distinction—that could be engineering, that could be art, that could be chemistry.”   How BJ’s new body liberated him [40:00]  “One of the ways to get through something in some real ways to let yourself be changed by it.” —BJ Miller Deciding to pursue medicine After graduating with an art history degree, BJ decided to go to medical school  BJ’s goal was NOT to not get back to where I was before the injuries, but rather let those experiences and lessons shape his path forward in a positive way Medicine lit up as a way to put these experiences to use— “I could apply these lessons into a therapeutic application of studying perspective and meaning-making.” “I was actively looking for an outlet where my injuries weren’t something that someone would look past or forgive, but were actually in some way something of an advantage.” How did BJ’s injuries liberated him Growing up, BJ had a sense that his life was almost too easy based on how others around him had it rough (mom with polio, sister with mental health issues) “My problem was I didn’t really have anything to complain about. I knew that life was really, really hard for many, many people and internally my life was hard.” After his injuries, he almost felt more comfortable in his new body— “I got the body that much more mirrored how I felt inside; fragmented, broken, confused, unintegrated, different.” This mental process of accepting his new body, that it was the “right” body for him, really removed the sense of regret and second guessing he otherwise would’ve felt   How losing his sister to suicide and his disillusionment with medicine altered his path [47:15]  His sister’s suicide After his sister’s suicide, she was diagnosed as having textbook bipolar disorder But even leading up to her death, she had everyone fooled including BJ, his parents, and even her therapist of 10 years—“she was a master manipulator” Before her death, BJ believed his sister was right about everything, “I saw Lisa was the standard. She was right. Everyone else was wrong.” His sister’s death led BJ to consider leaving medicine—he was demoralized that he was someone who wanted to heal people and yet he completely missed his sister’s diagnosis right under his nose How BJ found his path in medicine BJ has originally thought his path was going to be rehabilitation for people with traumatic injuries But soon into his residency he realized he hated it The whole idea of rehabilitation bothered him— It was so mechanical had nothing to do with the personal transformations The goal was  to get people back to where they were before the injury “I just don’t believe is true. It’s importantly untrue.” How his relationship with fear had changed: After his injuries, he was much less afraid of failure “I had a totally different relationship with fear. I saw falling as a skill.” —BJ Miller Ready to leave medicine: Going into medical school, he had promised himself he wouldn’t get stuck in something he didn’t like, life is too short He had also begun to be disillusioned with medicine–where the practice of medicine isn’t necessarily jiving with the ideals that you bring into it The dean talked him into doing his internship and he reluctantly agreed It was at that time that he stumbled into palliative care, “And that’s where everything changed”   Discovering his path of palliative care—distinct from hospice—in medicine [55:30]  Discovering palliative care BJ thought he understood what hospice was—simply where people go for the final days of lif Then one day he stumbled into an elective called “palliative care” at the Medical College of Wisconsin Dr. David Weissman was the oncologist there On this day, BJ witnessed a conversation that was a transformative moment for him: Dr. Weissman was having a conversation with a woman and he was trying to convey the serious nature of her heart condition It was type of tricky conversations that medicine traditionally doesn’t handle very well—very emotional, psychologically loaded content “He’s talking to her like a human being, not hovering over her like a superior, someone who’s there to fix her. It was beautiful.” The magic moment came when he looked at the patient in the eye and said, “When you die…” BJ was moved by how Dr. Weissman “dared to acknowledge this woman’s death” And on her face was not shock or anger, but relief  At that point, BJ knew that THIS was what he had been looking for In the world of palliative care… Illness, disability, death are normal, they’re not anomalous It’s not just the angle of the joint it was concerned with, but the angle of the thoughts and the way that we see ourselves The words we choose to describe our place in the world and how we either suffer for those words or how we really can find ourselves doing something more therapeutic “I’m not here to fix people, I’m here to be with people as they find their way and to deal with things that they can’t control. That was the hook for me.” —BJ Miller Difference between palliative care and hospice Palliative care in BJ’s words— Palliative care is simply the interdisciplinary pursuit of the quality of life Within the context of serious illness palliative care is that mode of care which helps you feel as well as possible—Emotionally, physically, spiritually There is nothing in the definition of palliative care that makes it that you need be dying anytime soon—Death is included in this, but it’s not the focus. The thing that we treat in palliative care is suffering, not disease Hospice care in BJ’s words— Hospice is a subset of palliative care—it is essentially palliative care that’s applied at the end of life That is a huge distinction — yet because many think palliative care and hospice are the same, nobody wants to talk about palliative care because of all the baggage around death Suffering is the consequence of conflating these terms— The consequence of conflating the two is that people suffer for years where they could get a lot more support through palliative care “They think [palliative care] is only relevant if you’re dying soon, and nothing could be farther from the truth.” —BJ Miller   Our complicated relationship with death, and how acknowledging it can release its grip and improve living [1:02:15]  Our complicated relationship with death Even though all of us are going to die, it seems we don’t live like that is a reality We are almost in denial, or just have an inability to look at death BJ says it understandable and that we should cut ourselves some slack We are wired to run away from death We’re also the only species who is aware of our own eventual mortality It’s quite a predicament we humans have, it’s a huge subject for us to wrap our heads around A victim of our own success—due to advancing technologies and medicine, we’ve been able to extend lifespan and forestall death So now that sense of urgency is lessened Put all that stuff together and we’ve conspired to set up a pretty tricky relationship to this piece of our nature “People die much more miserable than they need to because they haven’t dared to look at this thing called death before it’s too late.” —BJ Miller Life is precious specifically because we die Thanks to our technology, you can kind of live forever by some very reduced definition of life Once you look at death and really accept it as a reality, two things happen: 1) You many realize it’s not so terrifying afterall 2) Once you come to terms with the fact that your time is limited and therefore precious, it has a secondary effect of helping you really, really appreciate what you have “The fact that it ends is what makes it precious.” —BJ Miller We can do both We don’t have to pick between maximizing our lifespan and accepting death Instead, we can figure out a way to live the best life possible and the longest life possible  As long as we think it’s either life or death, that either you love life and try everything you can do to extend it, or you love death and just completely accept that it’s going to come today These false dichotomies are the problem   The different distinctions around the fear of death, and how BJ helps his patients negotiate fears [1:10:00] The different types of fear of death Many of BJ’s patient present with a fear of death, but there’s an important distinction— Are you afraid of the dying process? Or are you afraid of being dead? In the former,  there are medications to help the body come down for a “gentle landing” (i.e., not suffer in physical pain) So if that’s your fear, BJ offers his patients reassurance If you fear is about being dead – what happens next, leaving your family behind, missing out, etc. In this case, there is no clear “answer” But “as a fellow traveler, I can accompany you there. We can think about that together. We can talk about it and then we can make a life that responds to that big question.” Examples:  If someone is worried about “judgement day”, then the solution is to help them behave differently in the time they have left If someone’s fear is not living forever, “my favorite means to living forever is to think about the world beyond yourself; invest yourself in the world beyond yourself so when your self dies, that thing you love keeps going.” “This is where it gets really, really fascinating, the relationship between self and other and what to do about that. Religious thinking, spiritual pursuits, this is what can open up when you admit that you’re freaked out to be dead.” —BJ Miller Peter’s personal fear is around leaving his family behind, and missing out on the future generations BJ’s point is that you CAN live through those things, but you have to make the investment, it doesn’t happen automatically The irony is that you have to do it while you’re still alive and well, you can’t wait until your last moments Palliative care should really begin much earlier in life “It’s such a shame that we forestall and keep it at bay when it’s this thing that could help us so, so much.” “Whether actually a palliative care referral or a palliative care mindset, but one way or another finding our way into this subject while we’ve got plenty of road in front of us, is absolutely the right, best way.”   The major design flaws of a “death phobic” healthcare system [1:14:15] The big design flaw of medicine The overarching design flaw is that the system is focused on disease, not on the people dealing with disease The second you make it about the person living with the disease, not the disease itself, you welcome in all sorts of things into the mix beyond just their physiology and anatomy: Their social, emotional, and spiritual lives You’ve welcomed your humanness into the mix as a clinician being relevant beyond just your technical skills This can help with doctor burnout It also helps with the expectation management—doctors can not be expected to work miracles: “We know that at some day everyone’s going to die and that that’s not a failure for us.” “Once we align healthcare with the human condition and with serving human beings, so much of the trouble will work itself out.” —BJ Miller Palliative care should be apart of everything Given that 100% of patients die eventually, you’d think that palliative care would not need to be a specialty, it would be baked into how all of medicine works. The healthcare system itself can’t keep doing what it’s doing and can’t keep death the enemy, because it’s going to lose that war again and again and again. The wrong strategy and misaligned resources Peter says we’ve taken the wrong strategy in a war that probably ought to be deemed more of a truce We’ve put our resources in the wrong place medicine is very good is on acute care and really bad with chronic care And it has nothing to do with healthy life to prevent acute or chronic issues And it has nothing to do with death So, why do we keep doing that? In many cases, we don’t know what to do to prevent the condition And even the ones that we do understand, like obesity, we don’t really have the infrastructure to help with prevention In med school, for example… There isn’t a single course on dying Not a single course on nutrition or exercise or stress management Or the psychology of eating and our relationship to food and how you can help patients make better choices with nutrition and things like that Frankly physicians aren’t compensated for those types of things—You just don’t have the billable structure in which you can do these things Instead we focus on the drugs as our main tools, and drugs just aren’t good for the chronic conditions Summarizing the 3 design flaws of healthcare: 1 – We’re death phobic and we see ourselves as victors when we cure something But chronic illness by definition is something that we can’t fix This presents doctors with a sense of failure, which becomes an emotional barrier to developing it further 2 – The busy-ness of medicine Medicine is a series of transactions, which can work in acute care But with chronic care, you’ve got to learn to live with it so illness and health becomes protracted over time  Therefore chronic care becomes an experience, yet we’re wired for transactions so we don’t have the systems and structures in place to be cultivating experiences together with our patients. 3 – Reimbursement: Doctors are incentivized away from thinking about care over time   Common regrets, the value of time, and other insights from interactions with patients in their final moments of life [1:23:00] Common regrets from hospice patients BJ has had many of these intimate deathbed moments Of course, he sees the common regrets like wishing they had spent more time with family that at work But in most cases, the patient is dying from a chronic illness so they’ve had some protracted period of time to think about our death specifically By the later stages of their life, their regrets show up more often in wishing as: I wish I had dared to love more.  I wish I hadn’t been so afraid.  I wish I had just let myself be myself.  I wish I hadn’t been so hard on myself or criticized myself. The commonality is that they wish they had let themselves come to terms with death earlier in their lives, because it would have changed the decisions they made This is the freedom of coming to grips with death:  If “failure” is guaranteed, the pressure is OFF to live perfectly (always being a good person, eating veggies, not smoking, etc.” In parallel, the pressure is ON to take life seriously and be yourself A liberating force “The only thing I have to lose is wasting my time, so I’m not going to waste my time. I’m going to take this stuff seriously. I’m going to say what I want to say to people. I’m going to do what I want to do.” Accepting the inevitability of death is a way of forgiving yourself for “failing” “In this way, it can be a real liberating force… and the regrets have something to do with not coming to that place sooner.” —BJ Miller Addressing the dying wishes of patients BJ works with the Dream Foundation—an organization that helps make those wishes come true Visiting the Grand Canyon, for example “It’s beautiful” says BJ Helping fulfill those wishes is SOME of BJ’s job, and when it’s practical to do so, “It’s fun. It’s great work. It’s powerful. It’s delightful and it’s stunning.” However, BJ finds himself more commonly helping patients see themselves in the world in such a way that they can let go of those things that they never got to, because they realize the things that they’re not going to get to is a very long list. “On a developmental level, you’ve got to find a way to come to terms with all the things you’re not going to get to do. That’s where I spend a lot of my time.” Are people become enlightened and hyper transcendent at the end of life? Oftentimes, patients are so heavily medicated that they’re not really even able to communicate much with their loved ones—It’s the price we’ll pay to keep them comfortable The last day or two of life is not necessarily the greatest time to be digging into someone’s soul But it’s not an either/or situation—meaning take drugs and be out of it but pain free  OR don’t take drugs and be in pain but be lucid Intractable pain is a great route to delirium—when your body is an absolute agony is a pretty quick psychotic experience Threading the needle with palliative care: Palliative care doctors can often “thread a needle” and get someone comfortable enough, but not so overly medicated that they can’t interact But in the very final moments of life, you’re not having big philosophical conversations This is the best argument as to why there is no time like the present to say what it is you want to say to people who matter “There is no time like the present to say what it is you want to say to people who matter.” —BJ Miller   The story of Randy Sloan—a case study of playing life out [1:33:45] Meeting Randy Sloan BJ had a dream of riding a motorcycle which was a challenge given his amputations Randy Sloan was a young mechanic who gladly took on the challenge of fitting BJ on his own bike After modifying the bike, BJ had a “beautiful moment” where he was able to ride off into the sunset on his own Figure 2. B.J. Miller on the motorcycle that Randy Sloan helped make for him. Image credit: nytimes.com Randy’s diagnosis Not much longer, BJ got a call from Randy’s mother who told BJ that Randy had been diagnosed with an extremely rare cancer called mesothelioma Randy had only a few weeks to live from the moment of his diagnosis Figure 3. Randy Sloan. Image credit: nytimes.com Palliative care for Randy Randy immediately moved into the Zen Hospice Project where BJ worked at the time where he played out the rest of his life BJ had the sobering conversation with Randy that there was nothing that was going to help them at this point, except for love In that conversation, BJ asked Randy, “what are you most proud of in yourself?” Without hesitation, Randy replied, “I want everybody I ever come into contact to know that I love them.” From there the next steps became clear: We need to keep you as comfortable and conscious as possible for what time you have  Let’s get you into this hospice house and out of the charade of treatment Let’s treat your symptoms and open up your door and get as many people in here as you want And that’s what he did… He just had a steady stream of visitors.  “He became this radiant beam of love for what time he had and just made sure to love as many people as he humanly could.” “That became his legacy. And he died smiling and quickly.”   Hastening death with physician-assisted dying: Legality and considerations [1:39:45] Legality of assisted dying Physician-assisted dying (aka euthanasia) has been legalized in a handful of states (See list of states here) The process includes writing a letter for approval, there’s a 2 week wait, you have to have two physicians involved, etc. This is in place as a fail safe so that people don’t do something in a moment of weakness— “It’s almost like once you pierce the veil of indefinite life, which people really long for, on some levels think they long for, then all of a sudden they’re terminal. And then they can’t die soon enough.” It’s the ‘quit before getting fired impulse’, says BJ In the case of someone like Randy… BJ says if hastening death was an option for Randy, he could imagine him taking that route given that the world was falling apart so quickly and it was just too painful mentally and physically for a little while there for Randy to “see straight” But the realization that Randy had a mission to sort of prove love, to show love, to be love, he then had a reason to keep going Rather than choose assisted dying, Randy had a lot more final moments with friends and he had the pride of playing his body all the way out “A meaningful life, a good life, is not the absence of suffering. Suffering teaches us too much. It’s too important of a vehicle for us actually.
